intro: Leucopogon xerampelinus, commonly known as the narrow-leaved heath, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heaths and heather, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in acidic, well-drained soils and thrives in sandy or rocky habitats. Its leaves are narrow and leathery, providing a dense, low-growing structure, while its flowers are usually pink or white, appearing in clusters. Leucopogon xerampelinus plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, supporting pollinators and contributing to the biodiversity of its ecosystem.
